Description: Characteristics of deity.
Omniscient god. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 47 (Odin); Irish Myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.—So. Am. Indian (Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 173, (Guarani): Métraux BBAE CXLIII (3) 93.
All-seeing god. Jewish: Neuman; Greek: Aeschylus Suppliants line 138.
Immutable god. Jewish: Neuman.
Omnipotent god. Jewish: *Neuman.
Omnipresent god. Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.
Eternal god. Jewish: Neuman.
Holy god. Jewish: Neuman.
Sleepless god. Jewish: Neuman.
Invisible god. Jewish: Neuman.
Unity of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Purity of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Perfect God. Jewish: Neuman.
Loving kindness of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Goodness of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Modesty of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Justice of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Anger of God. Jewish: Neuman.
Imperfect god, subject to death and rebirth. Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 959.
Conflict between God's justice and mercy. Jewish: Neuman.
Father-god. Greek: Grote I 3; Hindu: Keith 50ff., 73ff., 82ff.; India: Thompson-Balys.
The making of gods.
Living person becomes god. Hawaii: *Beckwith Myth 2, ch. I passim.
Dead body becomes god. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 2.
Miscellaneous objects become gods. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 2.
Spirits become gods. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 45.

Opposition of good and evil gods. Hindu: Keith 84; *Penzer I 197; India: Thompson-Balys.—Tarahumare (Mexican Indian): Alexander N. Am. 176; S. Am. Indians (Antioquians): Alexander Lat. Am. 197.—Jewish: Neuman.
Gods and the demons quarrel over supremacy. India: Thompson- Balys.
Revolt of bad gods against good. Babylonian: Spence 75.
Goddess rebels against her father for forbidding her marriage. India: Thompson-Balys.

Revolt of evil angels against God. Jensen Dania II 180; Olrik ibid. II 67; Irish myth: Cross; India: Thompson-Balys; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3002, Legends Nos. 5, 6; Jewish: *Neuman; Irish: Beal. XXI 323.
Revolting devil banished to hell. India: Thompson-Balys; Jewish: Neuman.
Banished devil appears on earth only on day of dark moon. India: Thompson-Balys.
Demon (opposed to God) allowed to earth four times a year (but must let people know who he is and not deceive them). India: Thompson-Balys.
Satan's fall from heaven. Jewish: Neuman.
Created beings rebel against God. Jewish: Neuman.
Gods of darkness and light. Darkness thought of as evil, light as good.— Babylonian: Spence 74; Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.
God of the living and the dead in the otherworld. Chinese: Werner 248.
God of the dead. Irish myth: Cross; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 60.
Deity: miscellaneous motifs.
God as a triad. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 44; Icel.: Boberg.
Goddess as mother of Pacific Ocean. Maori: Beckwith Myth 179.
Origin of the gods.
Parents of the gods. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 171.

Mother of the gods. (cf. A116.2). **Showerman; Smith Dragon viii; *Holmberg Baum 84ff.—Babylonian: Spence 123ff.; Hindu: Penzer I 270ff., 276, VII 231; India: Thompson-Balys; Hittite: Garstang The Hittite Empire 305ff.; Gaster Thespis 179.—Oceanic: Beckwith Myth 294; So. Am. Indian (Apapocuvú-Guarani): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 122.
Father of the gods. Icel.: Boberg.
Ancestor of the gods. Tahiti: Henry 336.
God of double sex carries within him seed of gods. Greek: Grote I 16.
Hermaphroditic creator.
God dwells with his grandfathers. Marquesas: Handy 106.
Sea creatures as ancestors of goddess. Tuamotu: Stimson MS (T-G. 3/600).
Great bird as ancestor of gods. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 92.
Birth of gods. India: Thompson-Balys.
God from incestuous union. Krappe The Review of Religion (1941); India: Thompson-Balys.
God from father-daughter incest. Adonis. Greek: Spence 132.—Icel.: Boberg.
Goddess of music and dance born of incestuous union (Brahma and daughter). India: Thompson-Balys.
Male and female creators beget gods. Japanese: Anesaki 223.
Gods born from various parts of creator's body. Japanese: Anesaki 224.
God as son of giant. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 139 (Loki), 324 (Odin, Vili, and Ve), Boberg.
God as son of giantess. Icel.: Boberg.
Goddess as daughter of giant. Icel.: Boberg.
God as son of nine giantesses. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 153 (Heimdall).
Gods as sons of supreme god. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 61.—Tahiti: Henry 147.
God born from peculiar part of parent's body.
God born from mother's ear. Marquesas: Handy 107.
God born from mother's armpit. Marquesas: Handy 107.
Goddess born from mother's eyes. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 186.
God born after prematurely short pregnancy. Marquesas: Handy 107.
God from adulterous union. Irish myth: Cross.
Gods borne by human woman. India: Thompson-Balys.
Elementary spirits borne by human woman. India: Thompson- Balys.
Divine child cast out at birth. Polynesia: Beckwith Myth 257.
Child born from union of God with hen. Easter Is.: Métraux Ethnology 130.
Totemistic gods. Gods which have animal associations; e.g., Athena with the owl, Venus with the sparrow.—Babylonian: Spence 93; India: *Thompson-Balys; Irish myth: Cross.
Gods born from object.
Deity born from sea-foam. Aphrodite. Greek: Roscher I 402; *Frazer Pausanias III 544.
Goddess born from sweat of rock washed by sea. Minahassa (Celebes): Dixon 157.
God born of another god's sweat. India: Thompson-Balys.
Origin of lesser gods from spittle of great god. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 82.
God born from egg. Tahiti: Henry 337; Marquesas: Handy 104.—So. Am. Indian (Huamachuco): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 151.
Deity born in shape of egg. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 169.
Deity born from skull. Easter Is.: Métraux Ethnology 312.
Deity born from tree. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 279, 284.—So. Am. Indian (Tembé): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 122.
Emergence of deity.
First deity grows out of primeval chaos. Japanese: Anesaki 222.
God issues from earth. Norse: MacCulloch Eddic 328 (Tuisto).
Deity arises from mist. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 71.
Deity emerges from darkness of underworld. Mangia (Cook Is.): Beckwith Myth 224.
Emergence of gods from above and below. Marquesas: Handy 138.
Deity arises from shell of darkness where he has been for million ages. Tahiti: Henry.
Gods emerge from hole in tree. India: Thompson-Balys.

Twin gods. *Harris Twins, Boanerges, Picus who is also Zeus; Krappe Etudes de mythologie 137ff.; Güntert Weltkönig 253ff.; S. Eitrem Die göttlichen Zwillinge bei den Griechen (Christiania 1902); H. Grégoire Saints jumeaux et dieux cavaliers (Paris 1905); J.R. Harris The Dioscuri in the Christian Legends (London 1903); Krappe The Classical Journal XVIII (1923) 502ff.; Zeitschrift für Ethnologie LXVI (1929) 187ff.; "Les dieux jumeaux dans la religion germanique" Acta Philologica Scandinavica (1930); Review of Religion (1944) 123ff.; Revue Celtique XLIX (1932) 96ff; P. Saintyves, "Les Jumeaux, dans l'ethnographie et la mythologie," Revue Anthrop. XXXV (1925) 54—59; T. Gaster Oldest Stories 69.—Germanic: Helm Altgermanische Religionsgeschichte I 321ff.; Irish myth: Cross; Greek: Fox 26; Armenian: Ananikian 40; Hindu: Keith 30f. (Lettish also mentioned).—Zuсi: Alexander N. Am. 188; Mixtec: Alexander Lat. Am. 86; Indians of Central Brazil: Ehrenreich International Cong. of Americanists XIV 661; Chiriguano: Métraux RMLP XXXIII 172.
Twin gods—one mortal, other immortal. Harris Twins 4ff.
Twin goddesses (or trinity of goddesses). Irish myth: Cross.
Twin daughters of a god. India: Thompson-Balys.
Mortals become gods.
First men created with eternal life become gods. India: Thompson- Balys.
Mortal translated to heaven and deified. India: *Thompson-Balys; Maori: Clark Maori Folk Tales 167.
In extreme old age spirits become gods. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 67.
Mortal transfigured to god on mountain top. Maori: Beckwith Myth 250.
Gods are spirits of deified dead. Easter Is.: Métraux Ethnology 316.
Self-created deity. Tahiti: Henry 336f.
Origin of gods—miscellaneous.
God made by magic. Tahiti: Henry 341.—So. Am. Indian (Apapocuvá-Guarani): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 122.
Goddess produced by heat of earth. Tahiti: Beckwith Myth 178.
Arrival of the gods in particular country. Tonga: Gifford 199; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 2, 3, 11.
Nature and appearance of the gods. (cf. A18f.). Jewish: *Neuman.
God as shape-shifter. Irish myth: Cross.
Size-changing god. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 127.
Incorporeal god. Jewish: Neuman.
Formless gods. Tonga: Beckwith Myth 128.
Stars as deities. H. Gressmann Die hellenistische Gestirn-religion (Leipzig 1925); Gaster Thespis 228f.—Zuсi: Alexander N. Am. 187.
Moon as deity. (cf. A240). Jewish: Neuman.
Sun as deity. (cf. A220). Jewish: Neuman; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 217.
God half mortal, half immortal. Hair, skin, flesh, bones and marrow are mortal; mind, voice, breath, eye, and ear are immortal. (prajapati).—Hindu: Keith 76; cf. Greek: Grote I 3.
Monstrous gods. Jewish: Neuman.
God monstrous as to body.
Three-bodied goddess. Hekate has three bodies standing back to back and looking in three directions.—Greek: Fox 188.
God with two joined bodies. Tahiti: Henry 344.
God with good looking and ugly bodies. Marquesas: Handy 124.
God with body of earthquake (whirlwind, etc.). Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 30.
God with body of caterpillars. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 30.
God with body of stream of blood. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 30.
Goddess with three supernatural bodies: fire, cliff, sea. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 496.
God unusual as to face. Jewish: Neuman.
God with many faces.
God with two faces. *Krappe Balor 7 n. 24; Usener IV 347ff.; *Frazer Ovid II 95ff; India: Thompson-Balys.
God with three faces. *Krappe Balor 8 n. 28.—Chinese: Werner 324.
God with four faces. Greek: Roscher "Ianus"; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.
God with five faces. Jewish: Neuman.
God with six faces. Hindu: Penzer I 73 n. 1, II 102.
God's unusual mouth.
Maggots squirm from mouth of man-eating god. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 506.
Goddess with eight mouths. Tonga: Gifford 168.
God unusual as to eyes.
God with many eyes. *Krappe Balor 19ff. (Argos); Usener IV 223.—Hindu: Penzer II 46 n. 4, VIII 75, 116, IX 19; Keith 110, 134; Chinese: Werner 144.
Three-eyed god. *Usener IV 224 n. 1; *Frazer Pausanias III 209; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 32; India: Thompson-Balys.
God with hundred eyes. Irish myth: Cross; India: Thompson- Balys.
God with thirteen eyes. India: Thompson-Balys.
God with thousand eyes. India: Thompson-Balys.
Goddess with thousand eyes. India: Thompson-Balys.
God with flashing eyes. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 30; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 32.
God monstrous as to head.
God with many heads. Slavic (Elbe): Máchal 283f., Boberg. —Chinese: Werner 241, 321.
God with three heads. Irish myth: Cross.
God with seven heads. India: Thompson-Balys.
God with eight heads. Tahiti: Beckwith Myth 209.
God with head of stone. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 88.
God unusual as to arms.
God with many arms. Siva has ten arms.—Hindu: Keith 110; Chinese: Werner 144, 324.—Cf. Greek: Roscher "Briareos"; India: *Thompson-Balys; Irish Myth: Cross.
Marvels concerning God's arm and fingers. Jewish: Neuman.
God unusual at to legs (feet).
God with three legs. India: Thompson-Balys.
God unusual as to color.
Many-colored god. Hindu: Keith 81 (Shiva).
Black god(dess). Icel.: *Boberg, MacCulloch Eddic 304; W. Golther Deutsche Myth. (1895) 473f. (Hell); Hindu: Keith 126 (Krsna).
Goddess with one-and-a-half buttocks. India: Thompson-Balys.
Lotus plants grow from navel of Vishnu. India: Thompson-Balys.
God (deity) girdled with snakes; on his forehead shines the moon. India: Thompson-Balys.
God with tail. Mangaia (Cook Is.): Clark 140; Fiji: Beckwith Myth 76; Tahiti: Beckwith Myth 113.
Luminous god. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 129 (Balder); India: *Thompson- Balys.
God with luminous countenance. Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.
God with blazing eye. Hindu: Penzer VI 31 n. 1; India: *Thompson- Balys.
White god. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 152 (Heimdall), 129 (Balder).
Goddess with body full of fire. India: Thompson-Balys.
God's radiance upon Moses' face. Jewish: Neuman.
God in form of comet. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 113.
Deity in human form. (The human form is assumed in most mythologies.) —Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman; Samoa: Henry 346.
Goddess of war in shape of hag. Irish myth: Cross.
Goddess of war in shape of (red) woman. Irish myth: Cross.
God with red beard. Icel.: *Boberg.
God with gold teeth. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 153 (Heimdall).
Beautiful goddess. So. Am. Indian (Huarochiri): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 169.
Mutilated god. Egyptian: Müller 92ff.; Jewish: Neuman; Greek: Argonautica IV line 984 (Chronos); India: Thompson-Balys.
Blind god. Hödhr.—Icel.: Boberg, De la Saussaye 268.—India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Werner 284.

One-eyed god. Odin.—Harrison (Jane E.) Prolegomena to the Study of Greek Religion 194; Holmberg Finno-Ugric 179.—Irish myth: Cross; Icel.: Boberg, De la Saussaye 226, MacCulloch Eddic 21; Jewish: Neuman.
God with Evil Eye. Irish myth: Cross.
God with single eye, through lid of which passes a polished handle with which lid is lifted. Irish myth: Cross.
Legless and armless deity supported on animal. Borneo: Dixon 165.
God with one leg (foot). Irish myth: Cross.
God with one hand. Hand cut or bitten off.—*Krappe études 11ff.— Icel.: Boberg, MacCulloch Eddic 21 (Tyr); Irish myth: Cross.
Lame god. Greek: Fox 205 (Hephaistos).
God with thick (iron) shoe. Icel.: MacCulloch Eddic 159 (Vidarr).
Gods with animal features. *De Visser Die nicht menschengestaltigen Götter der Griechen (Leiden 1903).—Egyptian: Müller 15ff.—Mexican: Alexander Lat. Am. 57ff.—Irish myth: Cross.
God as part man, part fish. Babylonian: Spence 151 (Dagon); Assyrian: ibid. 216; Jewish: Neuman.—Samoa: Beckwith Myth 76.
God with elephant's face. Hindu: Penzer II 99ff., 125 n. 1, 147 n. 1, 170, III 155 n. 2, V 196, VII 131, IX 1.
Deity with animal's head.
Deity with cat's head. Irish myth: Cross.
Goddess with pig's head. Tonga: Beckwith Myth 178.
God with ram's head. (cf. A132.14). Egyptian: Müller 135, 405.—Irish myth: Cross.
God in tiger's skin. Hindu: Keith 81, 111; India: Thompson-Balys.
God with goat-feet. Greek: Fox 267 (Pan).
Horned god. Irish myth: Cross; Egyptian: Müller 38 (Hathors).
Winged god. Jewish: Neuman.
Goddess with pig's teeth. India: Thompson-Balys.

God in animal form. *De Visser Die nicht menschengestaltigen Götter der Griechen (Leiden, 1903).—Egyptian: Müller 15ff.; Chibcha: Alexander Lat. Am. 204 (fox, bear); Irish myth: Cross; India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: *Krappe "Far Eastern Fox Lore" CFQ III (1944) 124ff.; Jewish: Neuman.
God in successive animal forms. India: Thompson-Balys.
God takes form successively of ants, scorpion, and cobra. India: Thompson-Balys.
God in three forms: gecho, shark, or priest. Tonga: Beckwith Myth 128.
Snake-god. Smith Dragon 85.—Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman; Hindu: Penzer X 240 s.v. "Nagas"; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 139.—Fiji: Beckwith Myth 138, 316.
Deity has snake-children. India: Thompson-Balys.
Monkey as god. Chinese: Werner 325ff.; Hindu: Penzer II 73, 197 n. 2, IV 126, VIII 44; India: Thompson-Balys.
Equine god (goddess).
Horse-god. Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson- Balys.
Mule-god. Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.
Horse-goddess. Irish myth: Cross.
Ass-god. Jewish: Neuman.
Stag-god. Irish myth: Cross.
Bear-god (goddess). Irish myth: Cross.
Bird deity. Irish myth: Cross.
Bird-god. Irish myth: Cross.—Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 91ff., 370.
Goddess in form of bird. Irish myth: Cross.
Cock-god. Jewish: Neuman; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 119.
Female deities as fly-catchers. Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 16.
Pigeon-god. Tonga: Gifford 62.
Swine-god. Irish myth: Cross; India: Thompson-Balys.
Dog (wolf)-god. Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.
Bull-god. Irish myth: Cross.
Cow as god. India: Thompson-Balys.
Tiger-god. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Seal-god. Easter Is.: Métraux Ethnology 310.
Eel-god. Tonga: Gifford 57; Maori: Clark 163.
Fish-god. Tonga: Beckwith Myth 131, Gifford 79.
Ram-god. Icel.: Boberg; Jewish: Neuman.
God as tortoise. Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 139.
Giant god. (cf. A128.2). Irish myth: Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys.
